abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fourth Structural
            Adjustment Credit for Mali were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: When an operation, such as SAC IV,
            involves both policy reforms and budget support activities,
            there is a need to initiate budget support activities well
            in advance. In hindsight, in view of high fiscal risks
            entailed at that time, it was the correct decision on the
            part of the Bank to limit the focus of the project's
            cotton sector component on (i) measures to reduce the size
            of the deficit, and (ii) strengthening the cotton pricing
            mechanism as the first important step of the comprehensive
            cotton sector reforms. The project demonstrated that it is
            important to adopt a participatory approach and develop a
            systematic communication channel with the public for the
            success of these types of operations. It is important for
            the Bank to be consistent in its message, which should be
            based on technical considerations. For a SAC operation to
            succeed, it is important to limit the number of conditionalities.

5817505.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAC-IV) for Mali aims at: (i) contributing to broad-based
            growth and poverty reduction by strengthening fiscal policy
            and financial sector underpinnings of stable, long-run
            growth. Fiscal policy will be strengthened, inter alia, by
            developing medium-term expenditure policy consistent with
            poverty reduction objectives; strengthening the link between
            the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) and the budget;
            and limiting budget transfers to parastatal enterprises.
            Financial sector reform will be advanced by taking steps
            towards strengthening of the financial system, and limiting
            the risk of bank insolvency; (ii) improving efficiency,
            accountability, and transparency in public expenditure
            management. This will be achieved by strengthening budget
            preparation, execution, and controls, increasing
            transparency and disclosure including at decentralized
            levels, and helping ensure better monitoring of and access
            to basic services by the poor.
